reasoning: The critique targets a specific sub-argument in the position: the toy claim that in the limit cognitive labor could fully substitute for compute by AIs simulating experiments “in their heads,” used to motivate doubt that rho<0 can hold in the absolute limit. This point is not central to the overall case (the position offers many other reasons to expect higher substitutability in AI R&D), so centrality is low-to-moderate. Within that narrow target, the critique is fairly strong and mostly correct: any such “thinking” is still implemented on physical hardware and consumes compute, so it doesn’t straightforwardly show substitution under fixed-compute constraints; it at best shifts where compute is spent. The critique is clear, focused on a single issue, and contains no fluff. Overall impact on the position is limited because refuting this toy example doesn’t substantially undercut the broader set of counterarguments.
title: Mental simulation of neural nets still requires physical compute
